intro: Cracca villosa subsp. varia, commonly known as the hairy cracca, is a flowering plant native to parts of Europe and western Asia. It is a member of the Apiaceae family, which includes carrots and parsley, and is characterized by its finely hairy stems and leaves. The plant produces small, greenish-yellow flowers arranged in umbels, typical of the family. It thrives in dry, open habitats such as grasslands and rocky areas, often growing in full sun. Its morphology and distribution make it an important species for ecological studies in its native range.
